newsitem.title: USA: IMF's Camdessus believes EMU will start on schedule.
newsitem.headline: IMF's Camdessus believes EMU will start on schedule.

text.p: International Monetary Fund Managing Director Michel Camdessus said momentum for the European Union's planned common currency, the Euro, is strong and he believes it will be launched by January 1999.
Camdessus, speaking to reporters at a briefing, added that even if a delay beyond that date were to occur, it would not mean an end to the process.
"The progression towards EMU (economic and monetary union) is so strong, that even a delay should not derail it.
"But my belief at this stage is that it (delay) will not be necessary and that the Euro will be launched effective January 1999," he said.

"If further delay was needed, it wouldn't necessarily be a catastrophe, but the decision should be explained pretty well as well as the next deadline for completing the process," he said, referring to Europe's ambitious political project.
Camdessus said he welcomed an accord reached this week by France and Germany that kept the Euro on track.

"I see it as a compromise and an extremely constructive one," he said, referring to the pact which balanced French demands that the European Union make jobs and growth a priority and Germany's insistence on continued fiscal discipline.
"It's a more balanced approach of European policy," Camdessus said, adding, "I welcome that and I hope it will provide these countries with renewed enthusiasm."

Later, in a speech to the Los Angeles World Affairs Council, Camdessus discussed the risks associated with large capital inflows into emerging markets, noting that private flows to developing and transition economies reached a record high of $235 billion last year, or about five times the level in 1990.
He said large capital inflows can complicate domestic economic management, pressure exchange rates and can lead to a widening of the current account deficit in some countries.
He said the risks are great in countries where domestic banking systems and supervisions are weak.

"Having seen the state of banking systems around the world, the IMF has pointed to the need for a set of 'best practices' in the financial area that are intentionally recognized and applicable to countries at varying stages of development," he said.
Camdessus said the IMF is also encouraging all countries, especially those tapping, or hoping to tap, international capital markets to improve economic and financial data they provide to the public.
Transparency is one of several ways the IMF is hoping to raise the returns and reduce the risks in global capital markets.
"Better information makes for better investment decisions and fewer market surprises," he said.
Camdessus also said there is movement toward giving the IMF oversight over restrictions on capital movements.
"The emphasis will be on fostering the smooth operation of capital markets," he said, adding, "this is good for recipient countries, good for investors and good for the world economy."
